abstract.p: Mississippi State defeats Florida, 47-35, in college football; other results noted (M)

block.p: Mississippi State 47 Florida 35
Dicenzo Miller ran for 172 yards and Dontae Walker had 156 as Mississippi State made No. 3 Florida look defenseless in a 47-35 victory yesterday in Starkville, Miss.
Mississippi State 47 Florida 35
Dicenzo Miller ran for 172 yards and Dontae Walker had 156 as Mississippi State made No. 3 Florida look defenseless in a 47-35 victory yesterday in Starkville, Miss.
Florida Coach Steve Spurrier openly questioned his defense's effort after last week's poor performance against Kentucky and saw no improvement against the Bulldogs.
Mississippi State (3-1, 1-1 Southeastern Conference) gained 517 yards, 351 on the ground. Miller and Walker each had a touchdown run, and Wayne Madkin ran for two scores and threw for one.
Florida's offense wasn't much better against Mississippi State's pressure defense. The Gators (4-1, 2-1) turned the ball over three times and missed three fourth-and-1 attempts in the first half.
Florida scored a touchdown on the game's final play, but never got to attempt a conversion as fans stormed the field and tore down both goal posts.
L.S.U. 38, Tennessee 31
Rohan Davey threw a 25-yard touchdown pass to Robert Royal on the first play of overtime to give L.S.U. a victory over No. 11 Tennessee in Baton Rouge, La.
After L.S.U. scored, Tennessee drove to the 3, but third- and fourth-down passes to the end zone were broken up by linebacker Bradie James.
Tennessee did not score a touchdown until the third quarter, then scored 25 second-half points to overcome an 18-point deficit and tie the score.
L.S.U.'s John Corbello, who kicked a 47-yard field goal in the first quarter, missed a 46-yarder on the final play of regulation.
It was the first overtime game in Tiger Stadium history. Victory-starved L.S.U. fans swarmed the field after the game and quickly toppled both goal posts.
Oregon 23 Washington 16
Joey Harrington threw for one touchdown and ran for another to lead Oregon over visiting Washington.

Oregon (4-1, 2-0 Pac-10) led all the way after Harrington hit tight end Justin Peelle with a 13-yard strike up the middle midway through the first quarter. Harrington drove the Ducks 88 yards in nine plays after a 70-yard punt return by Keenan Howry was called back for an illegal Oregon block.
The victory extended Oregon's home winning streak to 18 games, the longest current streak in the Pac-10. It was the conference opener for Washington (3-1).
Oregon State 31 Southern Cal 21

Ken Simonton ran for a career-high 234 yards and three touchdowns as host Oregon State ended its 26-game losing streak against No. 8 Southern Cal. The last time the Beavers (4-0, 1-0 Pac-10) beat Southern Cal (3-1, 0-1) was a 3-0 victory over the Trojans in 1967.
Michigan 13 Wisconsin 10
Drew Henson, making his first start for No. 9 Michigan, threw a 15-yard touchdown pass to David Terrell with 6 minutes 42 seconds left at Ann Arbor, Mich.

The No. 17 Wolverines (4-1, 2-0 Big Ten) became the first Division I-A football program to reach 800 victories. The Badgers fell to 3-2, 0-2 in the Big Ten. Henson, who fumbled twice in the first quarter, was 15 of 27 for 257 yards and a touchdown.
On the game-winning drive, Henson converted on two third downs with 21- and 20-yard passes to Terrell.
Nebraska 42, Missouri 24
Eric Crouch ran for 110 yards and a touchdown and threw two scoring passes for No. 1 Nebraska.
Bobby Newcombe set a school record with a 94-yard punt return for a touchdown for the Cornhuskers (4-0, 1-0 Big 12), who won despite their worst defensive performance of the season.

The Huskers allowed a season-high 492 yards to the Tigers, who scored their most points in Lincoln since winning 35-31 in 1978 -- Missouri's last victory in the series. Newcombe's return broke Johnny Rodgers's school record of 92 yards set against Oklahoma State in 1971.
Kansas State 44 Colorado 21

Jonathan Beasley threw three first-half touchdown passes and visiting Kansas State opened its Big 12 campaign by overwhelming Colorado. Josh Scobey ran for two touchdowns for the No. 5 Wildcats (5-0), who scored three straight touchdowns after Colorado (0-4) had reduced the deficit to 7 midway through the second quarter.
Clemson 52, Duke 22

Woodrow Dantzler ran for three touchdowns and threw for another score as No. 7 Clemson beat Duke at Durham. Clemson (5-0, 3-0 Atlantic Coast Conference) has won its first five games for the first time since 1987 and is 17-3 against the Blue Devils (0-5, 0-2) in the last 20 meetings.
Alabama 27 South Carolina 17
Milo Lewis intercepted two fourth-quarter passes and the backup quarterback Andrew Zow revived a sputtering offense as host Alabama beat No. 23 South Carolina.
The Crimson Tide (2-3, 2-1 SEC) avoided its first 1-4 start in 43 years and handed the Gamecocks (4-1, 2-1) their first loss of the season.
T.C.U. 24, Navy 0

LaDainian Tomlinson ran for 121 yards and a touchdown as No. 16 Texas Christian University won at Navy to extend its winning streak to nine games. Casey Printers was 14 of 17 for 188 yards and 2 touchdowns for T.C.U. (4-0). Navy fell to 0-4. Tomlinson, who had 33 carries, broke T.C.U.'s career rushing record, pushing his total to 3,645 yards.
T.C.U. put together touchdown drives of 81, 85 and 67 yards, keyed by the passing of Printers.
Texas 42 Oklahoma State 7
Roy Williams caught a 96-yard touchdown pass and Kenny Hayter rushed for 122 yards against the nation's toughest run defense as No. 13 Texas beat visiting Oklahoma State.
Major Applewhite passed for 291 yards and 3 touchdowns to lead Texas (3-1, 1-0 Big 12).
Reggie White led Oklahoma State (2-2, 0-1) with 104 yards rushing.
Northwestern 37 Michigan State 17

No fluke. No overtime necessary. Northwestern beat a ranked team for the second straight week -- this time No. 18 Michigan State in East Lansing, Mich. The victory follows a riveting 47-44 overtime victory at Wisconsin, then ranked No. 7. Michigan State fell to 3-1.
IN OTHER GAMES

J.T. Thatcher had three interceptions as No. 14 OKLAHOMA (4-0, 1-0 Big 12) beat visiting KANSAS, 34-16. . . . Tellis Redmon ran for 183 yards on 31 carries and caught 3 passes for 116 yards as host MINNESOTA beat No. 24 ILLINOIS, 44-10. . . . Ben Leard threw two touchdown passes as No. 19 AUBURN defeated visiting VANDERBILT, 33-9. . . . Dewayne Woods scored on a 52-yard touchdown run late in the fourth quarter and No. 21 SOUTHERN MISSISSIPPI once again relied on its defense, beating visiting MEMPHIS, 24-3. . . . Jermaine Henderson scored on a 35-yard interception return on the Razorbacks' first play as No. 25 GEORGIA beat ARKANSAS, 38-7.
COLLEGE FOOTBALL: ROUNDUP
